results.title: Egypte
results.creator_credit: Al Razutis, John Taylor, Peter Jones, Don Worobey and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Time-lapse photography, combined with chanted music, gives an impressionistic and highly moving view of the great monuments of Egypt where art and civilisation once flowered some 5,000 years ago

results.title: Either-or
results.brief_description: Writes Forgacs: “Sensual and unknowing - perhaps this is the best metaphor to characterise the film. The families find protection from the terrors of socialism in the private sphere and the ancient human dramas, muffled amorous dependencies. The hardly visible yet palpable relationships are grasped by the viewer’s eyes…. In civil life, everything goes on even if the spontaneous actors do not see what they look at. This private film is exactly what is seems to be: the never-before-seen denouncer of invisible and sensual relationships.”

results.title: Jenny Watson, painter
results.brief_description:
“Jenny Watson, painter” is an interview Sue Ford conducted with fellow Australian artist Jenny Watson in 1975 at the latter’s studio and home on Punt Road, Richmond. The two artists discuss feminism, art and the relationship between art and life in this insightful interview and document of the time.

Jenny Watson (born 25 October 1951) is a leading Australian artist known for her practice intertwining painting with autobiographical and fictional narratives that interrogate the construction of femininity and self. Drawing from personal histories, punk and feminism, her painting practice has developed a unique style since the 1970s, incorporating fabric, text and collage. She has exhibited extensively in Australia and internationally, and her work is held in the collections of the Museum of Contemporary Art, the National Gallery of Australia and the National Gallery of Victoria.

In this 1975 interview, Watson reflects on the current state of art and the changes brought about by the introduction of video, performance, documentation and body art, highlighting the emergence of the personal or subjective within art practice. She discusses the difficulties facing women working in art such as a domestic situation, motherhood, or not being taken seriously; conversely, she points out the support provided by a community of women.

Watson goes on to discuss the shift towards the personal, figurative and diaristic in her recent work, particularly reflecting on the “Horse” series she created in the early 1970s. Filmed standing in front of her most recent body of work, a series of life-size portraits including one of her then-partner, artist John Nixon (“Yellow Painting: John”, 1974), and one of herself, Watson introduces the formal framework and her exploration of the subjective figure.

The interview is a fascinating insight into the development of an important Australian artist’s practice, as well as a testament to the interwoven personal relationships between artists of the period.

results.title: Eight martyrs = Ba nu tou jiang
results.creator_credit: Lu Chongzeng, Yang Guangyuan and August First Film Studio
results.brief_description:
The film is based on a true story during the anti-Japanese war in 1938. Leng Yun, a school teacher, could not bear her husband who worked for the Japanese, and went to join an anti-Japanese troop. Leng and seven other girls in the troop established good friendship. As winter came, the troop camped on a river bank but was attacked by the Japanese one night. In order to cover the troop to break through the siege, the eight girls fought alone with the Japanese until all their ammunition was used up. The Japanese had wanted to capture them alive, but the eight girls, with the eldest only twenty five and the youngest only thirteen years old, would rather die than surrender. They went hand in hand into the cold river in the end.

China’s state-owned film studios have produced many military films about the anti-Japanese war, and this is one of them. The military films mainly aim at patriotic education. Anti-Japanese films have become a sub-genre of war films in Chinese cinema.
Established on August 1, 1952, August First Film Studio is located in Beijing and under the management of the Chinese army. In the 1960s, China produced a series of anti-Japanese war films, among which some well-known ones include Little Soldier Zhang Ga and Tunnel War. The People’s Liberation Army of China was established on August 1st 1927. (3 stars - Yuxing Zhou; December 16, 2010)

results.title: Egypt and Turkey
results.brief_description: Visit Egypt ‘the gift of the Nile” with a recorded history of more than five thousand years and experience the antiquities of Egypt such as the Sphinx and Great Pyramid in Giza. Travel to Cairo with its contrast of most modern city in the Middle East, but also mirror to an ancient past in bazaars, antiquities and museums. Visit also Alexandria once ruled by Alexander the Great and Cleopatra. In Turkey, visit Istanbul and the Turquoise Coast. Istanbul spans two continents and has been the capital of three empires: Byzantine, Holy Roman and Ottoman. Walk through the city’s old sector to see the monuments of these cultures.

results.title: Egretta
results.brief_description: A life history of the four species of egrets commonly found in Australia, the white egret, the great egret, the white crane and the white heron.

results.title: Egghead's robot (Captioned)
results.creator_credit: Milo Lewis, Cecil Musk and Australian Council for Children's Film and Television
results.brief_description: A very funny comedy about Paul “Egghead” Wentworth, the son of an inventor, who makes a look-alike robot to do his chores and replace him at sports. All goes well until the robot is named “cricketer of the year”, then blows a fuse in the compost heap! Written by Leif Saxon. Rated: G

results.title: Effective resumes: resumes for maximum impact
results.creator_credit: Susan Richardson, Robert Richardson Jr and Riverside Productions
results.brief_description: This American video addresses the need for every job seeker (in particular young people), to have a resume and methods for laying it out, presentation and content. It presents tips for achieving an edge over other applicants.

results.title: Film technique: editing. Parts 1 and 2
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Film making techniques”.
Explains the editor’s responsibilities and summarises the various stages of editing. The first part deals mainly with the editing of silent films. The second part is more complex and discusses the editing of film with sound and synchronising sound and picture. Intended for film and TV trainees and technical colleges.
